elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig001">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Projection along the [100] direction of (CN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Nd(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, showing the layer which is formed by the packing of 12-membered apertures containing the guanidinium ions and the free water molecules. The symmetry codes are given in <ce:cross-ref refid="tbl003">Table 3</ce:cross-ref> and the thermal displacement parameters are 50%.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr002"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Projection along the [100] direction of (CN3H6)2[Nd(H2O)]2(C2O4)4⋅3H2O I, showing the layer which is formed by the packing of 12-membered apertures containing the guanidinium ions and the free water molecules. The symmetry codes are given in Table 3 and the thermal displacement parameters are 50%.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig002">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View along the <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> axis of two layers bridged, in-out-plane manner, by Ox3, for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>. The thermal displacement parameters are 50% except those of the carbon which are further reduced.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr003"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  View along the z axis of two layers bridged, in-out-plane manner, by Ox3, for I. The thermal displacement parameters are 50% except those of the carbon which are further reduced.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig003">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Perspective view along the [110] <ce:bold>A</ce:bold> and along the [−110] <ce:bold>B</ce:bold> directions, in <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, showing two different sets of channels. The thermal displacement parameters are 25%.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr004"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Perspective view along the [110] A and along the [-110] B directions, in I, showing two different sets of channels. The thermal displacement parameters are 25%.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig004">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Representation of the lanthanide polyhedron: 4 <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, Nd for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>; 4 <ce:bold>II A</ce:bold>, Nd1 for <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>; 4 <ce:bold>II B</ce:bold>, Nd2 for <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>; 4 <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, Yb for <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>. The thermal displacement parameters are 50%. The symmetry codes are given in <ce:cross-refs refid="tbl003 tbl005 tbl007">Tables 3, 5 and 7</ce:cross-refs> for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr005"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  Representation of the lanthanide polyhedron: 4 I, Nd for I; 4 II A, Nd1 for II; 4 II B, Nd2 for II; 4 III, Yb for III. The thermal displacement parameters are 50%. The symmetry codes are given in Tables 3, 5 and 7 for I, II and III, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig005">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View, along the [101] direction, of the layers formed by the packing of 10-membered apertures containing the TMA ions and the water molecules, for [N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Nd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>](C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3.5</ce:inf>⋅4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>. The symmetry codes are given in <ce:cross-ref refid="tbl005">Table 5</ce:cross-ref> and the thermal displacement parameters are 50%.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr006"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  View, along the [101] direction, of the layers formed by the packing of 10-membered apertures containing the TMA ions and the water molecules, for [N(CH3)4][Nd2(H2O)3](C2O4)3.5⋅4H2O II. The symmetry codes are given in Table 5 and the thermal displacement parameters are 50%.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig006">
<ce:label>Fig. 6</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Representation of two layers of [N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Nd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>](C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3.5</ce:inf>⋅4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> bridged by an oxalate unit, Ox2, showing two types of channels. The thermal displacement parameters are 50%.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr007"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  Representation of two layers of [N(CH3)4][Nd2(H2O)3](C2O4)3.5⋅4H2O II bridged by an oxalate unit, Ox2, showing two types of channels. The thermal displacement parameters are 50%.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig007">
<ce:label>Fig. 7</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View, along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, of the packing of the helices showing the square-cross section channels, for [N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Yb(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>. For clarity, the TMA ions are not represented. The symmetry codes are given in <ce:cross-ref refid="tbl007">Table 7</ce:cross-ref> and the thermal displacement parameters are 50%.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr008"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 7  View, along the c axis, of the packing of the helices showing the square-cross section channels, for [N(CH3)4][Yb(C2O4)2] III. For clarity, the TMA ions are not represented. The symmetry codes are given in Table 7 and the thermal displacement parameters are 50%.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig008">
<ce:label>Fig. 8</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Projection, along the <ce:italic>y</ce:italic> axis, of [N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Yb(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, showing the layer formed by the honey-comb of the 12-membered apertures containing only the TMA ions. The symmetry codes are given in <ce:cross-ref refid="tbl007">Table 7</ce:cross-ref> and the thermal displacement parameters are 50%.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr009"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 8  Projection, along the y axis, of [N(CH3)4][Yb(C2O4)2] III, showing the layer formed by the honey-comb of the 12-membered apertures containing only the TMA ions. The symmetry codes are given in Table 7 and the thermal displacement parameters are 50%.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig009">

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View, along the [114], of the 12-membered apertures containing the TMA ions, for <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>. The thermal displacement parameters are 50% except those of the carbon atoms which are further reduced.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr010"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 9  View, along the [114], of the 12-membered apertures containing the TMA ions, for III. The thermal displacement parameters are 50% except those of the carbon atoms which are further reduced.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Single crystals of three new lanthanide oxalate complexes, (CN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Nd(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, [N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Nd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>](C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3.5</ce:inf>⋅4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and [N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Yb(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, have been synthesized hydrothermally in presence of either the guanidinium or tetramethylammonium TMA ions. A relevant feature of <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> is the complete absence of water. For all the complexes, the three-dimensional framework structure is built up by the connections of the lanthanide and the oxalate units, forming cavities and channels where the guest species, guanidinium and TMA ions and free water molecules, are localized. Thus, the above complexes present a very open architecture. For <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, the neodymium atoms are 9-coordinated, forming a distorted monocapped square antiprism while for <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, the ytterbium atom is 8-coordinated forming a quite regular dodecahedron. For <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, the dehydration process is partially reversible. All the complexes will be characterized by infrared spectroscopy and thermal analysis. <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> has been extended to other lanthanide forming a family, Ln = La–Eu.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Single crystals of three new lanthanide oxalate complexes, (CN3H6)2[Nd(H2O)]2(C2O4)4⋅3H2O I, [N(CH3)4][Nd2(H2O)3](C2O4)3.5⋅4H2O II and [N(CH3)4][Yb(C2O4)2] III, have been synthesized hydrothermally in presence of either the guanidinium or tetramethylammonium TMA ions. A relevant feature of III is the complete absence of water. For all the complexes, the three-dimensional framework structure is built up by the connections of the lanthanide and the oxalate units, forming cavities and channels where the guest species, guanidinium and TMA ions and free water molecules, are localized. Thus, the above complexes present a very open architecture. For I and II, the neodymium atoms are 9-coordinated, forming a distorted monocapped square antiprism while for III, the ytterbium atom is 8-coordinated forming a quite regular dodecahedron. For I, the dehydration process is partially reversible. All the complexes will be characterized by infrared spectroscopy and thermal analysis. I has been extended to other lanthanide forming a family, Ln = La-Eu.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all"></ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In the last decade considerable attention has been afforded to search materials with an open-framework structure. Independently of zeolites and metal phosphates, which are well known, one of the most innovating approaches, in microporous materials, arises from metal–organic or metal-coordination chemistry . In such materials, organic moieties act as spacer or linker between the metal blocks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract



Introduction

In the last decade considerable attention has been afforded to search materials with an open-framework structure. Independently of zeolites and metal phosphates, which are well known, one of the most innovating approaches, in microporous materials, arises from metal-organic or metal-coordination chemistry . In such materials, organic moieties act as spacer or linker between the metal blocks.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="gr001"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para view="all">In the following, emphasis will be given to rare earth oxalates. Except from [Er(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>⋅12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O previously reported  and recently structurally described  which presents three-dimensional framework, the usual rare earth oxalates, either decahydrate or hexahydrate, are layered with honey-comb like apertures . Some mixed (M + Ln; M = alkaline element, ammonium; Ln = lanthanide, yttrium), with 2D and 3D structure, are known . Vaidhyanathan et al. were the first to have prepared four lanthanide oxalates, in presence of organic amines, which are three-dimensional with open architecture . For our part, we have already synthesized hydrothermally some 2D lanthanide oxalates, using the guanidinium ion as a template agent, (CN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)[La(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)](C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and (CN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)[Nd-(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
. The ammonium ion, observed in the latter complex, comes from a partial hydrolysis in situ of the guanidinium; such an hydrolysis has been previously reported for amines and is strongly dependent on the temperature and the time of treatment .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the following, emphasis will be given to rare earth oxalates. Except from [Er(H2O)3]2(C2O4)3⋅12H2O previously reported  and recently structurally described  which presents three-dimensional framework, the usual rare earth oxalates, either decahydrate or hexahydrate, are layered with honey-comb like apertures . Some mixed (M + Ln; M = alkaline element, ammonium; Ln = lanthanide, yttrium), with 2D and 3D structure, are known . Vaidhyanathan et al. were the first to have prepared four lanthanide oxalates, in presence of organic amines, which are three-dimensional with open architecture . For our part, we have already synthesized hydrothermally some 2D lanthanide oxalates, using the guanidinium ion as a template agent, (CN3H6)[La(H2O)](C2O4)2 and (CN3H6)(NH4)[Nd-(H2O)]2(C2O4)4 . The ammonium ion, observed in the latter complex, comes from a partial hydrolysis in situ of the guanidinium; such an hydrolysis has been previously reported for amines and is strongly dependent on the temperature and the time of treatment .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In this paper we have been able to isolate three-dimensional novel open-framework lanthanide oxalates, (CN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Nd(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, [N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Nd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>](C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3.5</ce:inf>⋅4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and [N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Yb(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, where organic amines, either guanidinium or tetramethylammonium ions, are localized into intersecting channels . The above complexes will be compared to those reported by Vaidhyanathan et al.  and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> will be specially compared to KY(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)⋅4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . Then, they will be characterized by infrared spectroscopy and by thermal analysis. In order to see if the free water could be exchanged, deuteration experiments will be realized for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>. At last <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, has been extended to some other lanthanides forming a family which extends from the lanthanum to the europium.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this paper we have been able to isolate three-dimensional novel open-framework lanthanide oxalates, (CN3H6)2[Nd(H2O)]2(C2O4)4⋅3H2O I, [N(CH3)4][Nd2(H2O)3](C2O4)3.5⋅4H2O II and [N(CH3)4][Yb(C2O4)2] III, where organic amines, either guanidinium or tetramethylammonium ions, are localized into intersecting channels . The above complexes will be compared to those reported by Vaidhyanathan et al.  and III will be specially compared to KY(C2O4)⋅4H2O . Then, they will be characterized by infrared spectroscopy and by thermal analysis. In order to see if the free water could be exchanged, deuteration experiments will be realized for I. At last I, has been extended to some other lanthanides forming a family which extends from the lanthanum to the europium.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The preparation of single crystals of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> was performed in Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (autogenous pressure), in presence of guanidine carbonate and tetramethylammonium hydroxide pentahydrate, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis and characterization

The preparation of single crystals of I, II and III was performed in Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (autogenous pressure), in presence of guanidine carbonate and tetramethylammonium hydroxide pentahydrate, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">For a typical synthesis of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, 2.5 mmol of oxalic acid and 2.5 mmol of guanidinium carbonate were added to an aqueous suspension (50 ml) of 0.5 mmol of Nd-oxalate decahydrate. The Nd-oxalate decahydrate was previously prepared according to the literature data . The addition of the oxalic acid upon guanidinium carbonate led to a CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> departure resulting in guanidinium oxalate. This starting mixture was stirred to attain homogeneity, sealed and heated at 120 °C, for one week.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For a typical synthesis of I, 2.5 mmol of oxalic acid and 2.5 mmol of guanidinium carbonate were added to an aqueous suspension (50 ml) of 0.5 mmol of Nd-oxalate decahydrate. The Nd-oxalate decahydrate was previously prepared according to the literature data . The addition of the oxalic acid upon guanidinium carbonate led to a CO2 departure resulting in guanidinium oxalate. This starting mixture was stirred to attain homogeneity, sealed and heated at 120°C, for one week.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">For the synthesis of <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, 5 mmol of oxalic acid, 2 mmol tetramethylammonium hydroxide pentahydrate were introduced into 10 ml of aqueous solution containing 1 mmol of Nd nitrate hexahydrate/Yb nitrate pentahydrate. The resulting mixture was heated for four weeks, at 150 or 120 °C for <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For the synthesis of II and III, 5 mmol of oxalic acid, 2 mmol tetramethylammonium hydroxide pentahydrate were introduced into 10 ml of aqueous solution containing 1 mmol of Nd nitrate hexahydrate/Yb nitrate pentahydrate. The resulting mixture was heated for four weeks, at 150 or 120°C for II or III, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">After cooling, the pH value of the solution was 5.8, 4.3 and 3.6 for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, respectively. In all the cases, single crystals, whose shapes are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl001"></ce:float-anchor>, were obtained. They were filtered, washed with distillated water and dried at ambient temperature. The yields of the complexes <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> to <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> were larger than 90%. X-ray diffraction patterns on powdered crystals indicated that new compounds were obtained. The patterns of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> were perfectly consistent with the single crystal structures of these complexes. For <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, a mixture of phases was observed, but the phase <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> was higher than 95%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: After cooling, the pH value of the solution was 5.8, 4.3 and 3.6 for I, II and III, respectively. In all the cases, single crystals, whose shapes are listed in  , were obtained. They were filtered, washed with distillated water and dried at ambient temperature. The yields of the complexes I to III were larger than 90%. X-ray diffraction patterns on powdered crystals indicated that new compounds were obtained. The patterns of I and II were perfectly consistent with the single crystal structures of these complexes. For III, a mixture of phases was observed, but the phase III was higher than 95%.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Another method of synthesizing the complex <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, as a powder, consisted of refluxing and stirring a suspension (100 ml) of lanthanide oxalate decahydrate with oxalic acid and guanidinium carbonate in a molar ratio variable between 1/5/5 and 1/3/3 for some days (2–5, according to the considered lanthanide). In that synthesis, instead of lanthanide oxalate, lanthanide nitrate might be used. With such a method, pure phase <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> was extended to some lanthanides, Ln = La–Eu (cf. Section ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Another method of synthesizing the complex I, as a powder, consisted of refluxing and stirring a suspension (100 ml) of lanthanide oxalate decahydrate with oxalic acid and guanidinium carbonate in a molar ratio variable between 1/5/5 and 1/3/3 for some days (2-5, according to the considered lanthanide). In that synthesis, instead of lanthanide oxalate, lanthanide nitrate might be used. With such a method, pure phase I was extended to some lanthanides, Ln = La-Eu (cf. Section ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Single-crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A suitable single crystal of each complex was carefully selected under an optical microscope. Data were collected on an Enraf Nonius four circles diffractometer equipped with a KAPPA-CCD detector. The intensity data were corrected for absorption, using a numerical method . For the three compounds, the structure solution was found using SIR 92  and the refinement were carried out using SHELXL-97 . Lanthanide, some oxygen and carbon atoms were located first and all the remaining non-hydrogen atoms were found by difference Fourier after iteration of least-square refinement. Hydrogen atoms, belonging to water and to the guanidinium (in <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>), were localized after difference Fourier syntheses while those, belonging to the tetramethylammonium (in <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>), were introduced geometrically. In all the cases, hydrogen atoms were riding at their relevant parent atoms. The set of physical and crystallographic characteristics, as well as the experimental conditions, are listed in . The atomic coordinates and equivalent thermal parameters are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl002"></ce:float-anchor>, selected bond lengths and angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl003"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl004"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl005"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal structure determination

A suitable single crystal of each complex was carefully selected under an optical microscope. Data were collected on an Enraf Nonius four circles diffractometer equipped with a KAPPA-CCD detector. The intensity data were corrected for absorption, using a numerical method . For the three compounds, the structure solution was found using SIR 92  and the refinement were carried out using SHELXL-97 . Lanthanide, some oxygen and carbon atoms were located first and all the remaining non-hydrogen atoms were found by difference Fourier after iteration of least-square refinement. Hydrogen atoms, belonging to water and to the guanidinium (in I), were localized after difference Fourier syntheses while those, belonging to the tetramethylammonium (in II and III), were introduced geometrically. In all the cases, hydrogen atoms were riding at their relevant parent atoms. The set of physical and crystallographic characteristics, as well as the experimental conditions, are listed in . The atomic coordinates and equivalent thermal parameters are given in  , selected bond lengths and angles are listed in    .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Description of structures</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">As previously mentioned in Section , the structures of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> are comparable enough but with some differences. They present a three-dimensional framework, which is built up by the linkage between the lanthanide atoms and the oxalate units forming cavities and channels, where are located guest species, guanidinium, TMA ions and free water molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of structures

As previously mentioned in Section , the structures of I, II and III are comparable enough but with some differences. They present a three-dimensional framework, which is built up by the linkage between the lanthanide atoms and the oxalate units forming cavities and channels, where are located guest species, guanidinium, TMA ions and free water molecules.

The Nd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Nd are rather homogeneous and they range from 6.3752(4) to 6.4541(6) and 6.4883(6) for Ox3, Ox2 and Ox1, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
(CN3H6)2[Nd(H2O)]2(C2O4)4⋅3H2O I 

The asymmetric unit of I contains 20 non-hydrogen atoms of which 14 are involved in the framework. There are one neodymium atom and three independent bis-chelating oxalate groups (Ox1, Ox2 and Ox3) (). The latter two are centrosymmetric. The NdNd are rather homogeneous and they range from 6.3752(4) to 6.4541(6) and 6.4883(6) for Ox3, Ox2 and Ox1, respectively.

elements.clean_text: As depicted in  , each neodymium atom is bound to three oxalate units and the connectivity between these species forms an honey-comb layer, with 12-membered apertures, along the a axis. Within such elliptic apertures (about  8 × 5  Å2  , including the Van der Waals radii) are located the guanidinium ion, the water molecule Ow1 linked to the neodymium and the free water molecules, Ow2 and Ow3. A supplementary oxalate, Ox3, bridges these layers in an out-of-plane fashion, ensuring the three-dimensionality and forming 12-membered channels (about  9.4 × 4.4  Å2  ) which run along the z axis ( ). The distance between the layers is  a / 2 = 7.0920 ( 7 )  Å . The guest species are located in these channels into the interlayer space.

<ce:para view="all">The neodymium atom is 9-coordinated with eight oxalate oxygen atoms and one water molecule, Ow1. The Nd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O distances range from 2.460(2) to 2.584(2) Å (average 2.509 Å) and are usual for such a lanthanide () . The coordination polyhedron of the neodymium atom is a distorted mono-capped square antiprism, with O4, the longer distance from the neodymium atom, occupying the cap position (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig004"></ce:float-anchor>

Only one oxalate is noncentrosymmetric, Ox1. This latter is planar within 0.007(2) Å. The C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O, C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C and O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O distances and angles are in the expected range for this type of bonding () .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The neodymium atom is 9-coordinated with eight oxalate oxygen atoms and one water molecule, Ow1. The NdO distances range from 2.460(2) to 2.584(2) Å (average 2.509 Å) and are usual for such a lanthanide () . The coordination polyhedron of the neodymium atom is a distorted mono-capped square antiprism, with O4, the longer distance from the neodymium atom, occupying the cap position (  I). The two square faces make a dihedral angle of 10.02(8)°. As usual for a lanthanide element, the three oxalate units are bischelating. Only one oxalate is noncentrosymmetric, Ox1. This latter is planar within 0.007(2) Å. The CO, CC and OCO distances and angles are in the expected range for this type of bonding () .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The guanidinium ion is planar within 0.002(2) Å and presents roughly the D<ce:inf loc="post">3h</ce:inf> symmetry. The C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N and N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N distances and angles range from 1.322(4) to 1.336(4) Å and from 119.1(3)° to 120.8(3)° (). They are normal for such an ion . This ion is tilted with respect to the mean plane of layer, a dihedral angle of 74.2(5)° is observed between these two planes. The hydrogen atoms of this ion form strong hydrogen bonding, either normal or bifurcated, through the oxalate oxygen atoms and Ow1 of the frame (). The free water molecules, Ow2 and Ow3, interact also with the frame by O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:glyph name="ptbdbd"></ce:glyph>O bonds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The guanidinium ion is planar within 0.002(2) Å and presents roughly the D3h symmetry. The CN and NCN distances and angles range from 1.322(4) to 1.336(4) Å and from 119.1(3)° to 120.8(3)° (). They are normal for such an ion . This ion is tilted with respect to the mean plane of layer, a dihedral angle of 74.2(5)° is observed between these two planes. The hydrogen atoms of this ion form strong hydrogen bonding, either normal or bifurcated, through the oxalate oxygen atoms and Ow1 of the frame (). The free water molecules, Ow2 and Ow3, interact also with the frame by OHO bonds.

elements.clean_text:
[N(CH3)4][Nd2(H2O)3](C2O4)3.5⋅4H2O II 

It crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group  P  2 1  / n . The asymmetric unit contains 35 non-hydrogen atoms which are, 2 independent neodymium atoms, 3.5 oxalate units (Ox1, Ox2, Ox3 and Ox4, ), one tetramethylammonium ion and 4 free water molecules. Ox4 is centrosymmetric. Although the coordination scheme of Ox2 to Ox4 was only bischelating, the one of Ox1 is bischelating plus monodentate via the oxygen atom O3 ( ): in fact, two Nd1 atoms share an edge, O3O3iii, the angle O3NdO3iii is 63.2(1)°. As a consequence, the NdNd distances are divided in two sets: 4.4892(5) Å (edge sharing between two Nd1 atoms), 6.2496(4) and 6.5138(4) Å between the three Nd atoms (2Nd1 + 1Nd2) bridged by Ox1, 6.4096(4), 6.4391(5) and 6.5221(6) Å through the bischelating Ox2, Ox4 and Ox3, respectively. The connectivity between Nd atoms and Ox1, Ox3 and Ox4 form a 10-membered-ring (3 Nd1 and 2 Nd2 atoms) and the packing of these rings results in a layer parallel to (101) plane. Within these rings, are formed elliptic cavities  ( 7.3 × 8.1  Å2  )  or partially channels occupied by the TMA ion and the free water molecules. Ox2 bridges the layers in out-of-plane manner, ensuring the three-dimensionality ( ). In this figure, two sets of cavities or channels, running along the  [ - 101 ]  direction, are observed: the smaller ones  ( 6.4 × 4.5  Å2  )  contain only some free water molecules while the TMA ions and some free water molecules occupy 12-membered puckered cavities  ( 8.3 × 4.4  Å )  of the larger ones.

elements.clean_text: The two neodymium atoms are 9-fold coordinated, with 7 oxalate oxygen atoms and 2 water molecules for Nd1 and with 8 oxalate oxygen atoms and one water molecule for Nd2. For Nd1, due to the unusual coordination scheme of Ox1, the distribution of distance is rather large from 2.429(3) to 2.674(3) Å  ( Δ = 0.245  Å )  (average 2.522 Å). Its coordination polyhedron can be represented as a distorted monocapped square antiprism, with O3 the longer distance from Nd1 occupying the cap position ( II A). A dihedral angle of 1.7(2)°, between the two square faces, is observed. For Nd2, the distribution of distances is narrower: from 2.489(3) to 2.534(3) Å  ( Δ = 0.045  Å )  (average 2.511 Å). Its coordination polyhedron is again a distorted monocapped square antiprism, with O4 occupying the cap position ( II B). A dihedral angle of 7.8(2)°, between the two square faces, is observed.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The variation of the distances Nd1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O is also reflected in the C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bonding of Ox1. The O3 atom, involved in edge sharing between 2 Nd1 atoms, moves further away from C2 (1.277(5) Å) while the O4 atom goes nearer (1.238(5) Å) (). The other distances and angles of the oxalate units are in the range expected for this type of bonding. Such variations are also noticed by comparing the planarity of the noncentrosymmetric oxalate groups, Ox1 to Ox3. Ox1 is roughly ten times more deformed (0.072(2) Å) than Ox2 or Ox3 (0.011(2) and 0.007(2) Å, respectively).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The variation of the distances Nd1O is also reflected in the CO bonding of Ox1. The O3 atom, involved in edge sharing between 2 Nd1 atoms, moves further away from C2 (1.277(5) Å) while the O4 atom goes nearer (1.238(5) Å) (). The other distances and angles of the oxalate units are in the range expected for this type of bonding. Such variations are also noticed by comparing the planarity of the noncentrosymmetric oxalate groups, Ox1 to Ox3. Ox1 is roughly ten times more deformed (0.072(2) Å) than Ox2 or Ox3 (0.011(2) and 0.007(2) Å, respectively).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The TMA ion is close to the tetrahedral configuration. The distances N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C range from 1.446(7) to 1.487(7) Å and the relevant angles range from 107.4(5)° to 111.6(5)°, they are comparable with the literature data . The nearest oxygen atom of the framework (O1<ce:sup loc="post">vii</ce:sup>) is distant from the C10 atom by 3.039(7) Å. Note, that the distance N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C10 is the highest. The water molecules, free or bound to the Nd atoms, are linked either to themselves or to the oxygen atoms of the framework via strong hydrogen bonds ().</ce:para>

The nearest oxygen atom of the framework (O1vii) is distant from the C10 atom by 3.039(7) Å. Note, that the distance NC10 is the highest. The water molecules, free or bound to the Nd atoms, are linked either to themselves or to the oxygen atoms of the framework via strong hydrogen bonds ().

elements.clean_text:
[N(CH3)4][Yb(C2O4)2] III 

This complex crystallizes in the tetragonal system, space-group  I  4 1  / a . The ytterbium and the nitrogen atoms are located in particular positions, 4a and 4b, respectively. The other atoms occupy general positions ( ). As previously, the framework can be understood in terms of connections between the ytterbium atom and the oxalate unit. Each ytterbium is surrounded by four oxalate units, giving rise to channels with a square-cross section, running along the  [ 001 ]  direction ( ). But as can be seen on this figure, such channels are given by helices spreading to the c axis. Two adjacent helices share an oxalate unit and they turn in an opposite sense. In the other directions  [ 100 ]  ( ) and  [ 010 ]  (not represented, it is approximately the same than ), the packing of these helices leads to channels with a 12-membered elliptic channels  ( 6.4 × 10.3  Å2  ) , where are localized the TMA ions, two ions by each aperture. Other channels appear for example along the  [ 114 ]  ( ) and the  [ 11  - 4 ]  (not represented) directions. All these channels are partially intersecting.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The ytterbium is 8-coordinated with only oxalate oxygen atoms. The distances Y<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O range from 2.301(2) to 2.379(2) Å (average 2.340 Å) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl007"></ce:float-anchor>). The ytterbium coordination polyhedron is a dodecahedron. For this type of polyhedron, one distance Yb<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O is longer than the other . One can describe this polyhedron either as interpenetrating tetrahedron forms, one elongated (O1) and the other flattened (O2), or as two trapezoids O2<ce:sup loc="post">iv</ce:sup>, O1, O1<ce:sup loc="post">v</ce:sup>, O2<ce:sup loc="post">iii</ce:sup> and O2<ce:sup loc="post">i</ce:sup>, O1<ce:sup loc="post">vi</ce:sup>, O1<ce:sup loc="post">vii</ce:sup>, O2<ce:sup loc="post">ii</ce:sup> which lie in mutually orthogonal mirror planes (observed 90.00(6)°) (
<ce:bold>III</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The ytterbium is 8-coordinated with only oxalate oxygen atoms. The distances YO range from 2.301(2) to 2.379(2) Å (average 2.340 Å) ( ). The ytterbium coordination polyhedron is a dodecahedron. For this type of polyhedron, one distance YbO is longer than the other . One can describe this polyhedron either as interpenetrating tetrahedron forms, one elongated (O1) and the other flattened (O2), or as two trapezoids O2iv, O1, O1v, O2iii and O2i, O1vi, O1vii, O2ii which lie in mutually orthogonal mirror planes (observed 90.00(6)°) ( III).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The bond distances and angles of the oxalate unit are normal. Due to the particular position of the nitrogen atom, the TMA group presents a quite regular tetrahedron configuration, with distances and angles quite normal () . The nearest oxygen atom of the frame (O2) is distant from the C2 atom of the TMA group by 3.327(7) Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The bond distances and angles of the oxalate unit are normal. Due to the particular position of the nitrogen atom, the TMA group presents a quite regular tetrahedron configuration, with distances and angles quite normal () . The nearest oxygen atom of the frame (O2) is distant from the C2 atom of the TMA group by 3.327(7) Å.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">It is worthwhile to notice that this complex, synthesized in an aqueous medium, is completely anhydrous. Hydrothermal synthesis provides, generally, less water than normal synthesis but to our knowledge, the number of lanthanide oxalate completely free from water is scarce, (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)[La(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] , [C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>][Y(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is worthwhile to notice that this complex, synthesized in an aqueous medium, is completely anhydrous. Hydrothermal synthesis provides, generally, less water than normal synthesis but to our knowledge, the number of lanthanide oxalate completely free from water is scarce, (NH4)[La(C2O4)2] , [C5N2H12][Y(C2O4)2] .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Comparison of the above complexes with some structures reported in literature</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The structures of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> to <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> present some comparable features to those of some framework lanthanide oxalate described recently.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">They are similar enough to four 3D compounds [C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>][Y(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], [C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>[Y(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]⋅2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, [NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Nd(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HCOO)]⋅H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O [OC(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(NCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)CH(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Nd(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HCOO)]⋅H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O recently reported by Vaidhyanathan et al. . For these compounds, as it is the case of our complexes, the organic moieties are localized into 12-membered apertures or channels but in the fourth compound the organic group is also bound to neodymium via the oxygen atom and that is unusual. The presence of 12-membered apertures or channels is a common feature of lanthanide oxalates, they are present in layered simple lanthanide oxalate, whether decahydrate or hexahydrate .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of the above complexes with some structures reported in literature

The structures of I to III present some comparable features to those of some framework lanthanide oxalate described recently.

They are similar enough to four 3D compounds [C5N2H12][Y(C2O4)2], [C6N2H16]0.5[Y(H2O)(C2O4)2]⋅2H2O, [NH3CH2CH(NH3)CH3][Nd(C2O4)2(HCOO)]⋅H2O [OC(CH3)(NCH2)CH(CH3)NH3][Nd(C2O4)2(HCOO)]⋅H2O recently reported by Vaidhyanathan et al. . For these compounds, as it is the case of our complexes, the organic moieties are localized into 12-membered apertures or channels but in the fourth compound the organic group is also bound to neodymium via the oxygen atom and that is unusual. The presence of 12-membered apertures or channels is a common feature of lanthanide oxalates, they are present in layered simple lanthanide oxalate, whether decahydrate or hexahydrate .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">More uncommon is the presence of 10-membered apertures presented by the complex <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>. Such feature is due to the coordination scheme of one oxalate, bis-chelating and monodentate. Generally, the ligand oxalate is bis-chelating, but higher are the temperature and time of hydrothermal treatment higher is the number of metal atoms bridged by this ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: More uncommon is the presence of 10-membered apertures presented by the complex II. Such feature is due to the coordination scheme of one oxalate, bis-chelating and monodentate. Generally, the ligand oxalate is bis-chelating, but higher are the temperature and time of hydrothermal treatment higher is the number of metal atoms bridged by this ligand.

elements.clean_text: At last, III presents some structural feature with YK(C2O4)⋅4H2O which Audebrand et al. considered as a structure type . Indeed, these two compounds crystallize in the tetragonal symmetry, space group  I  4 1  / a , but with different unit-cell constants (for YK(C2O4)⋅4H2O,  a = 11.4621 ( 8 )  Å  and  c = 8.9040 ( 8 )  Å ; for III, see in ). The same coordination polyhedron of the lanthanide is observed, quite regular dodecahedron. Furthermore, they present, along the c axis, square-cross channels and along a and b axes 12-membered channels where are localized either the potassium ions and the water molecules or the TMA ions. Thus, III and YK(C2O4)⋅4H2O are isotypic: the only difference is the replacement of potassium ions and of water molecules by tetramethylammonium ions. At our knowledge, III is the first lanthanide oxalate, containing protonated amine, presenting such structure .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Thermal behavior of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The TGA curves of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> complexes are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig010"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">For <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, the total mass loss agree well with its formula, leading to Nd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (observed 60.4% against theoretical 60.44%). The dehydration phenomenon occurs, between 100 and 175 °C and the observed mass loss is 9.8% (theoretical 10.58%). Then, a well-defined plateau, corresponding to the anhydrous compound is observed from 175 to 300 °C. The second mass loss starts smoothly, then it becomes steeply, in the temperature range 350–380 °C, to end on a singular point at this latter temperature (departure of guanidinium ion and partly of the oxalate ion). At this point, the compound can be Nd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (observed, 33.9% versus theoretical 34.33%). The following curve does not differ with the one of simple neodymium oxalate which has been the subject of many studies .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal behavior of I, II and III 

The TGA curves of I, II and III complexes are presented in  .

For I, the total mass loss agree well with its formula, leading to Nd2O3 (observed 60.4% against theoretical 60.44%). The dehydration phenomenon occurs, between 100 and 175°C and the observed mass loss is 9.8% (theoretical 10.58%). Then, a well-defined plateau, corresponding to the anhydrous compound is observed from 175 to 300°C. The second mass loss starts smoothly, then it becomes steeply, in the temperature range 350-380°C, to end on a singular point at this latter temperature (departure of guanidinium ion and partly of the oxalate ion). At this point, the compound can be Nd2(CO3)3 (observed, 33.9% versus theoretical 34.33%). The following curve does not differ with the one of simple neodymium oxalate which has been the subject of many studies .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">For <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>, its formula is in agreement with the total mass loss, leading again to Nd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (observed 58.0% against theoretical 57.75%). The dehydration loss is two step process; it starts about 50 and at 275 °C, only six water molecules would be lost. The loss of the latter water molecule is observed at temperature higher than 275 °C and overlaps with the decomposition of the frame (departure of one water molecule, TMA and partly of the oxalate groups) until a singular point about 385 °C, where the compound would be Nd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (observed 22.3% versus theoretical 21.84%). After this singular point, the TGA curve is similar to this of neodymium oxalate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For II, its formula is in agreement with the total mass loss, leading again to Nd2O3 (observed 58.0% against theoretical 57.75%). The dehydration loss is two step process; it starts about 50 and at 275°C, only six water molecules would be lost. The loss of the latter water molecule is observed at temperature higher than 275°C and overlaps with the decomposition of the frame (departure of one water molecule, TMA and partly of the oxalate groups) until a singular point about 385°C, where the compound would be Nd2(C2O4)(CO3)2 (observed 22.3% versus theoretical 21.84%). After this singular point, the TGA curve is similar to this of neodymium oxalate.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">For <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, its formula agree well with the total mass loss leading to Yb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (52.9% versus theoretical 53.42%). The result of the TGA curve is a proof again that this compound is completely anhydrous, even that this compound is not a pure phase (<mml:math altimg="si105.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mo>∼</mml:mo>
<mml:mn>95</mml:mn>
<mml:mtext>%</mml:mtext>
</mml:math> cf. Section ). The decomposition is a three stages overlapping process with two inflexion points, at about 420 and 435 °C, where the compounds could be Yb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) and Yb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, respectively (observed 30.8% and 42.2% versus theoretical 31.20% and 43.02%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For III, its formula agree well with the total mass loss leading to Yb2O3 (52.9% versus theoretical 53.42%). The result of the TGA curve is a proof again that this compound is completely anhydrous, even that this compound is not a pure phase ( ~ 95 %  cf. Section ). The decomposition is a three stages overlapping process with two inflexion points, at about 420 and 435°C, where the compounds could be Yb2(C2O4)2(CO3) and Yb2(CO3)2O, respectively (observed 30.8% and 42.2% versus theoretical 31.20% and 43.02%).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">By decomposing lanthanide oxalates, such mixed anionic, oxalate–carbonate, carbonate–oxide, lanthanide compounds have been reported . But we still ignored why such compound appears instead of the other by decomposing <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>. It is likely that the departure of the protonated amine and consequently of a partial departure of the oxalate ligand induces an activation energy which leads to the various observed compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: By decomposing lanthanide oxalates, such mixed anionic, oxalate-carbonate, carbonate-oxide, lanthanide compounds have been reported . But we still ignored why such compound appears instead of the other by decomposing I, II and III. It is likely that the departure of the protonated amine and consequently of a partial departure of the oxalate ligand induces an activation energy which leads to the various observed compounds.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Furthermore, the onset of the decomposition of the oxalate ligands, for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> occurs at a temperature similar to those of simple neodymium and ytterbium oxalates. By heating, the 3D compounds behave like the 2D simple lanthanide oxalates.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, the onset of the decomposition of the oxalate ligands, for I, II and III occurs at a temperature similar to those of simple neodymium and ytterbium oxalates. By heating, the 3D compounds behave like the 2D simple lanthanide oxalates.

elements.clean_text:
Infrared spectra of I, II and III 

The infrared spectra of compounds I, II and III are presented in  . Independently of oxalate bands (1500-1650, 1490, 1315, 1355 and 795 cm-1) which appear in all the spectra, at practically the same position, and which are a constant feature of the whole family of simple lanthanide oxalate , these spectra differ:   - The I spectrum exhibits two bands at 3572, 3425 cm-1 and a weak massif centered at 1105 cm-1 attributed, respectively, to asymmetric, symmetric stretching and rocking vibrations of H2O and four more or less overlapping bands at 3265, 3205, 3050 and 2920 cm-1 which are characteristic two by two of   ν as   and   ν s   of NH2 of the guanidinium ion .   - For clarity sake, the III spectrum will be explained before II one. This spectrum presents a lot of bands, from 3185 to 2515 cm-1 characteristic of   ν as   and   ν s   of CH3 of the TMA ion and two bands 1425 and 1455 cm-1 due to the bending of the methyl, which are overlapping the strong oxalate massif and at last a sharp band at 960 cm-1 assigned to   ν as   (NC) . A weak massif centered at 3425 cm-1, due to the water, is also present. It is uneasy to avoid such a trace of water, when the sample is ground with KBr, and such a small massif of water seems to be attributable to the grinding phenomenon.   - The II spectrum becomes more explainable. The band, attributed previously to   ν as   (NC) of the TMA ion, is present also at 960 cm-1. Concerning the stretching vibrations of the methyl, it is uneasy to disclose them, due to an important proportion of water. In fact, they are completely masked by the strong water massif.

All these results are coherent with the structure of these compounds, as well as their thermal analysis.

Dehydration process of I 

 I will be submitted to deuteration experiments. The infrared spectra are displayed in  . The I spectrum is the starting product, the   I '   spectrum corresponds to this product heated, at 150°C for 8 h, under   p   D 2  O   ~ 20  Torr  and the   I "   is the latter product treated again, in the same conditions, under   p   H 2  O   ~ 20  Torr .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">By weighing the sample before and after the treatment, no sensible weigh is noted. The above infrared results show that the dehydration process is partially reversible. Similar D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O exchange, although much limited, is made by heating at 100 °C in the same conditions. However, heating at this latter temperature leads to a widening of XRD peaks but by heating at 150 °C the compound is in an amorphous state. However, the open-structure is still present.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: By weighing the sample before and after the treatment, no sensible weigh is noted. The above infrared results show that the dehydration process is partially reversible. Similar D2OH2O exchange, although much limited, is made by heating at 100°C in the same conditions. However, heating at this latter temperature leads to a widening of XRD peaks but by heating at 150°C the compound is in an amorphous state. However, the open-structure is still present.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Extension of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> to some lanthanides</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">
<ce:bold>I</ce:bold> has been extended to some lanthanide elements, La–Eu, particularly by refluxing (cf. Section ). This family ends to the europium and furthermore to obtain this last element, as a pure phase, 5 days are required while for the neodymium, for example, 2 days are needed. The cell-constants of all the family are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl008"></ce:float-anchor>. They agree well with the so-called lanthanide contraction, versus the lanthanide radius  and furthermore they respect somewhat the Vegard rule.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Extension of I to some lanthanides

 I has been extended to some lanthanide elements, La-Eu, particularly by refluxing (cf. Section ). This family ends to the europium and furthermore to obtain this last element, as a pure phase, 5 days are required while for the neodymium, for example, 2 days are needed. The cell-constants of all the family are presented in  . They agree well with the so-called lanthanide contraction, versus the lanthanide radius  and furthermore they respect somewhat the Vegard rule.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Three novel 3D lanthanide oxalate complexes, which present a very open architecture, have been synthesized hydrothermal technique, in presence of organic amines, guanidinium or tetramethylammonium. For <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, the dehydration process is partially reversible.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three novel 3D lanthanide oxalate complexes, which present a very open architecture, have been synthesized hydrothermal technique, in presence of organic amines, guanidinium or tetramethylammonium. For I, the dehydration process is partially reversible.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The supplementary materials has been sent to the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 union road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ UK, under the numbers, CCDC 243119, CCDC 2431120 and CCDC 243121 for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

The supplementary materials has been sent to the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 union road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ UK, under the numbers, CCDC 243119, CCDC 2431120 and CCDC 243121 for I, II and III, respectively.

cln_elements.content: <ce:para view="all">For a typical synthesis of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, 2.5 mmol of oxalic acid and 2.5 mmol of guanidinium carbonate were added to an aqueous suspension (50 ml) of 0.5 mmol of Nd-oxalate decahydrate. The Nd-oxalate decahydrate was previously prepared according to the literature data . The addition of the oxalic acid upon guanidinium carbonate led to a CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> departure resulting in guanidinium oxalate. This starting mixture was stirred to attain homogeneity, sealed and heated at 120 °C, for one week.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">For the synthesis of <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, 5 mmol of oxalic acid, 2 mmol tetramethylammonium hydroxide pentahydrate were introduced into 10 ml of aqueous solution containing 1 mmol of Nd nitrate hexahydrate/Yb nitrate pentahydrate. The resulting mixture was heated for four weeks, at 150 or 120 °C for <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
For a typical synthesis of I, 2.5 mmol of oxalic acid and 2.5 mmol of guanidinium carbonate were added to an aqueous suspension (50 ml) of 0.5 mmol of Nd-oxalate decahydrate. The Nd-oxalate decahydrate was previously prepared according to the literature data . The addition of the oxalic acid upon guanidinium carbonate led to a CO2 departure resulting in guanidinium oxalate. This starting mixture was stirred to attain homogeneity, sealed and heated at 120°C, for one week.

For the synthesis of II and III, 5 mmol of oxalic acid, 2 mmol tetramethylammonium hydroxide pentahydrate were introduced into 10 ml of aqueous solution containing 1 mmol of Nd nitrate hexahydrate/Yb nitrate pentahydrate. The resulting mixture was heated for four weeks, at 150 or 120°C for II or III, respectively.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">After cooling, the pH value of the solution was 5.8, 4.3 and 3.6 for <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, respectively. In all the cases, single crystals, whose shapes are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl001"></ce:float-anchor>, were obtained. They were filtered, washed with distillated water and dried at ambient temperature. The yields of the complexes <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> to <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> were larger than 90%. X-ray diffraction patterns on powdered crystals indicated that new compounds were obtained. The patterns of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> were perfectly consistent with the single crystal structures of these complexes. For <ce:bold>III</ce:bold>, a mixture of phases was observed, but the phase <ce:bold>III</ce:bold> was higher than 95%.</ce:para><ce:section-title>(CN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Nd(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>⋅3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>I</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> contains 20 non-hydrogen atoms of which 14 are involved in the framework. There are one neodymium atom and three independent bis-chelating oxalate groups (Ox1, Ox2 and Ox3) (). The latter two are centrosymmetric. The Nd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Nd are rather homogeneous and they range from 6.3752(4) to 6.4541(6) and 6.4883(6) for Ox3, Ox2 and Ox1, respectively.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">As depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig001"></ce:float-anchor>, each neodymium atom is bound to three oxalate units and the connectivity between these species forms an honey-comb layer, with 12-membered apertures, along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis. Within such elliptic apertures (about <mml:math altimg="si58.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mn>8</mml:mn>
<mml:mo>×</mml:mo>
<mml:mn>5</mml:mn>
<mml:mspace width="0.25em"></mml:mspace>
<mml:mtext>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</mml:mtext>
</mml:math>, including the Van der Waals radii) are located the guanidinium ion, the water molecule Ow1 linked to the neodymium and the free water molecules, Ow2 and Ow3. A supplementary oxalate, Ox3, bridges these layers in an out-of-plane fashion, ensuring the three-dimensionality and forming 12-membered channels (about <mml:math altimg="si59.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mn>9.4</mml:mn>
<mml:mo>×</mml:mo>
<mml:mn>4.4</mml:mn>
<mml:mspace width="0.25em"></mml:mspace>
<mml:mtext>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</mml:mtext>
</mml:math>) which run along the <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> axis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig002"></ce:float-anchor>). The distance between the layers is <mml:math altimg="si60.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mi>a</mml:mi>

<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>
<mml:mo>=</mml:mo>

cln_elements.clean_text:
After cooling, the pH value of the solution was 5.8, 4.3 and 3.6 for I, II and III, respectively. In all the cases, single crystals, whose shapes are listed in  , were obtained. They were filtered, washed with distillated water and dried at ambient temperature. The yields of the complexes I to III were larger than 90%. X-ray diffraction patterns on powdered crystals indicated that new compounds were obtained. The patterns of I and II were perfectly consistent with the single crystal structures of these complexes. For III, a mixture of phases was observed, but the phase III was higher than 95%.

(CN3H6)2[Nd(H2O)]2(C2O4)4⋅3H2O I 

The asymmetric unit of I contains 20 non-hydrogen atoms of which 14 are involved in the framework. There are one neodymium atom and three independent bis-chelating oxalate groups (Ox1, Ox2 and Ox3) (). The latter two are centrosymmetric. The NdNd are rather homogeneous and they range from 6.3752(4) to 6.4541(6) and 6.4883(6) for Ox3, Ox2 and Ox1, respectively.

As depicted in  , each neodymium atom is bound to three oxalate units and the connectivity between these species forms an honey-comb layer, with 12-membered apertures, along the a axis. Within such elliptic apertures (about  8 × 5  Å2  , including the Van der Waals radii) are located the guanidinium ion, the water molecule Ow1 linked to the neodymium and the free water molecules, Ow2 and Ow3. A supplementary oxalate, Ox3, bridges these layers in an out-of-plane fashion, ensuring the three-dimensionality and forming 12-membered channels (about  9.4 × 4.4  Å2  ) which run along the z axis ( ). The distance between the layers is  a / 2 = 7.0920 ( 7 )  Å . The guest species are located in these channels into the interlayer space.

[N(CH3)4][Nd2(H2O)3](C2O4)3.5⋅4H2O II 

It crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group  P  2 1  / n . The asymmetric unit contains 35 non-hydrogen atoms which are, 2 independent neodymium atoms, 3.5 oxalate units (Ox1, Ox2, Ox3 and Ox4, ), one tetramethylammonium ion and 4 free water molecules. Ox4 is centrosymmetric. Although the coordination scheme of Ox2 to Ox4 was only bischelating, the one of Ox1 is bischelating plus monodentate via the oxygen atom O3 ( ): in fact, two Nd1 atoms share an edge, O3O3iii, the angle O3NdO3iii is 63.2(1)°. As a consequence, the NdNd distances are divided in two sets: 4.4892(5) Å (edge sharing between two Nd1 atoms), 6.2496(4) and 6.5138(4) Å between the three Nd atoms (2Nd1 + 1Nd2) bridged by Ox1, 6.4096(4), 6.4391(5) and 6.5221(6) Å through the bischelating Ox2, Ox4 and Ox3, respectively. The connectivity between Nd atoms and Ox1, Ox3 and Ox4 form a 10-membered-ring (3 Nd1 and 2 Nd2 atoms) and the packing of these rings results in a layer parallel to (101) plane. Within these rings, are formed elliptic cavities  ( 7.3 × 8.1  Å2  )  or partially channels occupied by the TMA ion and the free water molecules. Ox2 bridges the layers in out-of-plane manner, ensuring the three-dimensionality ( ). In this figure, two sets of cavities or channels, running along the  [ - 101 ]  direction, are observed: the smaller ones  ( 6.4 × 4.5  Å2  )  contain only some free water molecules while the TMA ions and some free water molecules occupy 12-membered puckered cavities  ( 8.3 × 4.4  Å )  of the larger ones.

The two neodymium atoms are 9-fold coordinated, with 7 oxalate oxygen atoms and 2 water molecules for Nd1 and with 8 oxalate oxygen atoms and one water molecule for Nd2. For Nd1, due to the unusual coordination scheme of Ox1, the distribution of distance is rather large from 2.429(3) to 2.674(3) Å  ( Δ = 0.245  Å )  (average 2.522 Å). Its coordination polyhedron can be represented as a distorted monocapped square antiprism, with O3 the longer distance from Nd1 occupying the cap position ( II A). A dihedral angle of 1.7(2)°, between the two square faces, is observed. For Nd2, the distribution of distances is narrower: from 2.489(3) to 2.534(3) Å  ( Δ = 0.045  Å )  (average 2.511 Å). Its coordination polyhedron is again a distorted monocapped square antiprism, with O4 occupying the cap position ( II B). A dihedral angle of 7.8(2)°, between the two square faces, is observed.

Thermal behavior of I, II and III 

The TGA curves of I, II and III complexes are presented in  .

For I, the total mass loss agree well with its formula, leading to Nd2O3 (observed 60.4% against theoretical 60.44%). The dehydration phenomenon occurs, between 100 and 175°C and the observed mass loss is 9.8% (theoretical 10.58%). Then, a well-defined plateau, corresponding to the anhydrous compound is observed from 175 to 300°C. The second mass loss starts smoothly, then it becomes steeply, in the temperature range 350-380°C, to end on a singular point at this latter temperature (departure of guanidinium ion and partly of the oxalate ion). At this point, the compound can be Nd2(CO3)3 (observed, 33.9% versus theoretical 34.33%). The following curve does not differ with the one of simple neodymium oxalate which has been the subject of many studies .

For II, its formula is in agreement with the total mass loss, leading again to Nd2O3 (observed 58.0% against theoretical 57.75%). The dehydration loss is two step process; it starts about 50 and at 275°C, only six water molecules would be lost. The loss of the latter water molecule is observed at temperature higher than 275°C and overlaps with the decomposition of the frame (departure of one water molecule, TMA and partly of the oxalate groups) until a singular point about 385°C, where the compound would be Nd2(C2O4)(CO3)2 (observed 22.3% versus theoretical 21.84%). After this singular point, the TGA curve is similar to this of neodymium oxalate.

decomposition temperature.type: departure of guanidinium ion and partly of the oxalate ion
departure of one water molecule, TMA and partly of the oxalate groups

cln_elements.clean_text:
For III, its formula agree well with the total mass loss leading to Yb2O3 (52.9% versus theoretical 53.42%). The result of the TGA curve is a proof again that this compound is completely anhydrous, even that this compound is not a pure phase ( ~ 95 %  cf. Section ). The decomposition is a three stages overlapping process with two inflexion points, at about 420 and 435°C, where the compounds could be Yb2(C2O4)2(CO3) and Yb2(CO3)2O, respectively (observed 30.8% and 42.2% versus theoretical 31.20% and 43.02%).

Infrared spectra of I, II and III 

The infrared spectra of compounds I, II and III are presented in  . Independently of oxalate bands (1500-1650, 1490, 1315, 1355 and 795 cm-1) which appear in all the spectra, at practically the same position, and which are a constant feature of the whole family of simple lanthanide oxalate , these spectra differ:   - The I spectrum exhibits two bands at 3572, 3425 cm-1 and a weak massif centered at 1105 cm-1 attributed, respectively, to asymmetric, symmetric stretching and rocking vibrations of H2O and four more or less overlapping bands at 3265, 3205, 3050 and 2920 cm-1 which are characteristic two by two of   ν as   and   ν s   of NH2 of the guanidinium ion .   - For clarity sake, the III spectrum will be explained before II one. This spectrum presents a lot of bands, from 3185 to 2515 cm-1 characteristic of   ν as   and   ν s   of CH3 of the TMA ion and two bands 1425 and 1455 cm-1 due to the bending of the methyl, which are overlapping the strong oxalate massif and at last a sharp band at 960 cm-1 assigned to   ν as   (NC) . A weak massif centered at 3425 cm-1, due to the water, is also present. It is uneasy to avoid such a trace of water, when the sample is ground with KBr, and such a small massif of water seems to be attributable to the grinding phenomenon.   - The II spectrum becomes more explainable. The band, attributed previously to   ν as   (NC) of the TMA ion, is present also at 960 cm-1. Concerning the stretching vibrations of the methyl, it is uneasy to disclose them, due to an important proportion of water. In fact, they are completely masked by the strong water massif.

decomposition temperature.type: three stages overlapping process with two inflexion points
